description: From Middle French manufacture, from Old French, from Medieval Latin manūfactūra (“a making by hand”), from manūfactus, a compound of manū factus, manū being ablative of manus (“hand”), and factus past participle of faciō (“I do, make”).

entries.meaning: The action or process of making goods systematically or on a large scale.
Anything made, formed or produced; product.
examples: The roads [are] crowded with carriers, laden with rich manufactures.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) The process of such production; generation, creation.
examples: Our lawgivers take special pride in the ever active manufacture of new bills and laws.

entries.meaning: (horology) A watch manufacturer that makes its own parts, rather than assembling watches from parts obtained from other firms.

verbs.description: manufacture (third-person singular simple present manufactures, present participle manufacturing, simple past and past participle manufactured)

entries.meaning: To make things, usually on a large scale, with tools and either physical labor or machinery.
(transitive) To work (raw or partly wrought materials) into suitable forms for use.
(derogatory) To fabricate; to create false evidence to support a point.
